r:Description.r:Content: Usage: ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Title of the CDC XML document - note that the Study Title goes in /ddi:DDIInstance/s:StudyUnit/r:Citation/r:Title/r:String.
Required: Mandatory if '..r:Title/r:String' element is present
Usage: ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used if available for the language.

Usage: This element serves two use cases. (1) Unique archival number. If no such number available, a PID may be used alternatively (and in such a case, the PID must be captured in this element *as well as* in "/ddi:DDIInstance/s:StudyUnit/r:Citation/r:InternationalIdentifier/r:IdentifierContent"). The @typeOfUserID attribute must be "StudyNumber". (2) A URL or URN (a reference to a web resource that specifies its location) linking to the study description on the SP website. CDC provides a link from the study information there to the study description on the SP website, to allow users to access the data. [This element not visible in the UI, it is only needed for the link]. The @typeOfUserID attribute must be "URLServiceProvider".
Usage: Must be specifed when the "ddi:DDIInstance/s:StudyUnit/r:UserID" element is used for the unique archival number.
Usage: Must be specifed when the "ddi:DDIInstance/s:StudyUnit/r:UserID" element is used for the URL of the study description at the SP website.
Usage: Title of the Study (as opposed to the title of the XML document).
Usage: Language of the study title. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Reference to Principal investigator Person OR Institution.
Usage: Type of object being referenced - in this case, it should always be either "Individual" or "Organization".
Usage: A reference to the name of the institution publishing the metadata, i.e. the name of the actual CESSDA Service Provider providing the metadata information. Only on study level.
Usage: Type of object being referenced - in this case, it should always be either "Individual" or "Organization".

Usage: Ideally 'YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ' format, but can accept 'YYYY-MM-DD', 'YYYY-MM' or 'YYYY' as date format. It is strongly recommended to provide the full date to allow sorting by publication date in CDC.
Usage: Used for the study PID. PID must be one of these four types: ARK, DOI, Handle or URN.

Usage: Agency responsible for the persistent identifier of the study. Value should be one of https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/vocabulary/CessdaPersistentIdentifierTypes i.e. ARK or DOI or Handle or URN.
Usage: The abstract for the study.
Usage: Language of the abstract. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Reference to the Agency which provided the funding.
Usage: Type of Agency which provided the funding. Should be 'Organization'.
Usage: If different funding agencies sponsored different stages of the production process, use 'r:FunderRole' to distinguish the grant numbers.

Usage: The identification code of the grant or other monetary award which provided funding for the Study. If you know that the funder is included in the OpenAIRE list of Funders, see the instructions for grantNo syntax here: https://guidelines.openaire.eu/en/latest/data/field_contributor.html#nameidentifier-ma-o . Indicate the appropriate agency using the r:AgencyOrganizationReference element. If different funding agencies sponsored different stages of the production process, use the /r:FunderRole element to distinguish the grant numbers.

Usage: Subject classifcation term for the study in the local language. Use descriptive terms from https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/vocabulary/TopicClassification if possible but other vocabularies are permitted.
Required: Mandatory if "/r:TopicalCoverage/r:Subject" element is present
Usage: Language of the subject classification term. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: The name of the vocabulary. If possible, use "CESSDA Topic Classification" (regardless of language) but other vocabularies are permitted.

Usage: Use the URI of the CV version that is being used based on the pattern "https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/urn/urn:ddi:int.cessda.cv:TopicClassification:[version number]" For example, for version 4.2 of CESSDA Topic Classification, use "https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/urn/urn:ddi:int.cessda.cv:TopicClassification:4.2.2".
Usage: Keyword for the study in the local language.
Required: Mandatory if 'keyword' element is present
Usage: Language of the keyword. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Required: Recommended if 'keyword' element is present
Usage: Source of keywords - ELSST is recommended but other vocabularies can be referenced.
Optional but note that if @vocab="ELSST", then use "https://elsst.cessda.eu/id" here.
Usage: Countries relevant to the study area.
Required: Mandatory if '..r:SpatialCoverage/r:Description/r:Content' element is present
Usage: Language of the country label. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Use this element only if the country has an ISO 3166-1 2-letter code.
Usage: Contains the Analysis Unit code value in English.
Usage: Use the string "DDI Analysis Unit" regardless of language.
Usage: The Canonical URL of the CV version that is being used e.g. https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/v2/vocabularies/AnalysisUnit/1.0.0?languageVersion=en-1.0.0.
Usage: Descriptive term of Analysis Unit CV item in the local language.
Required: Mandatory if 'AnalysisUnitsCovered' element is present
Usage: Language of the Analysis Unit descriptive term. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Should always be set as 'Related Publication'.
Usage: PID of the publication. Required by OpenAIRE to to relate the publication to a dataset.

Usage: Agency responsible for the identifier of the publication. Required by OpenAIRE and the value has to come from their controlled list of relatedIdentifierTypes: https://guidelines.openaire.eu/en/latest/data/field_relatedidentifier.html#d-relatedidentifier.
Usage: URL of website on which the publication can be found (or at least information concerning the literature).
Usage: Description of population or other elements studied or measured (freetext).
Required: Mandatory if '../c:Universe/r:Description/r:Content' element is present.
Usage: Language of the Universe item. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.

Usage: The default value is "true" in DDI-L. The description statement of a universe is generally stated in inclusive terms such as "All persons residing in Europe". Occasionally a universe is defined by what it excludes, i.e., "All persons residing in Europe except for those residing on U.S. Military bases". In this case the value would be changed to "false". In DDI-C, attribute clusion states the inclusion/exclusion with values "I" and "E" respectively.
Usage: Code value of the CV "DDI Time Method". Describes the time dimension of the data collection.
Usage: Use the string "DDI Time Method" regardless of language.
Usage: The Canonical URL of the CV version that is being used e.g. "https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/v2/vocabularies/TimeMethod/1.2.0?languageVersion=en-1.2.0".
Usage: Descriptive term of Time Method CV item in the local language.
Required: Mandatory if '.../d:TimeMethod/r:Description/r:Content' element is present
Usage: Language of the Time Dimension descriptive term. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Type of sampling procedure used for data collection. Controlled vocabulary includes a typology of sampling methods. Code value of the CV "DDI Sampling Procedure".
Usage: Use the string "DDI Sampling Procedure" regardless of language.
Usage: The Canonical URL of the CV version that is being used e.g. "https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/v2/vocabularies/SamplingProcedure/1.1.1?languageVersion=en-1.1.1".
Usage: Descriptive term of the Sampling Procedure CV item in the local language.
Required: Mandatory if '.../d:SamplingProcedure/r:Description/r:Content' element is present
Usage: Language of the Sampling Procedure Descriptive term. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Either a single point in time or start of a date range. Ideally YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ format, but can accept YYYY-MM-DD, YYYY-MM or YYYY.
Usage: End of a date range. If data collection period is a single event, then this element is not required. Ideally YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ format, but can accept YYYY-MM-DD, YYYY-MM or YYYY.
Usage: Use if data collection period is a single event. Ideally YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ format, but can accept YYYY-MM-DD, YYYY-MM or YYYY.
Usage: This is the free text expression of the collection period. This element may be empty.
Required: Mandatory if '...Content' element is populated with a freetext expression.
Usage: Language of the free text expression of the collection period. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
Usage: Description of the method of data collection - the procedure, technique, or mode of inquiry used to attain the data. Code value of the CV "DDI Mode of Data Collection".
Usage: Use the string "DDI Mode of Collection" regardless of language.
Usage: The Canonical URL of the CV version that is being used e.g. "https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/v2/vocabularies/ModeOfCollection/3.0?languageVersion=en-3.0.0".
Usage: Descriptive term of the Mode of Data Collection CV item in the local language.
Required: Mandatory if '.../d:ModeOfCollection/r:Description/r:Content' element is present
Usage: Language of the Mode of Data Collection descriptive term. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.

Usage: Controlled description of the data access (open access vs. restricted access). CDC will use the same Access Rights vocabulary as OpenAIRE. The name of the vocabulary is âinfo:eu-repo-Access-Terms vocabularyâ - see http://purl.org/eu-repo/semantics/#info-eu-repo-AccessRights Only the codes ârestrictedAccessâ and âopenAccessâ will be used.
Required: Mandatory if '../a:AccessTypeName' element is present
Usage: Refers to any information relating to the access and use conditions of data that the SP wants to appear in the CDC.
Required: Mandatory if '..a:Access/r:Description/r:Content' element is present
Usage: Language of the Access statement. ISO 639-1 codes are strongly encouraged to be used.
